issue.title: Enable Joint ForceTorque Tests for Bullet
Enable Joint ForceTorque Tests for Bullet
Enable Joint ForceTorque Tests for Bullet

content.raw:
ForceTorque1 and ForceTorque2 are passing for me, but GetForceTorqueWithAppliedForce is failing with bullet 2.82:

~~~
$ ldd gazebo/physics/UNIT_Joint_TEST | grep Bullet
	libBulletDynamics.so.2.82 => /usr/lib/bullet_2.82/libBulletDynamics.so.2.82 (0x00007fb8ff8bb000)
	libBulletCollision.so.2.82 => /usr/lib/bullet_2.82/libBulletCollision.so.2.82 (0x00007fb8ff5ce000)
~~~

issue.title: Enable Joint ForceTorque Tests for Bullet

content.raw: @scpeters It's looking like the explicit joint damping is causing the system to exhibit unstable behavior.
content.html: @scpeters It's looking like the explicit joint damping is causing the system to exhibit unstable behavior.

issue.title: Enable Joint ForceTorque Tests for Bullet

content.raw: Should I just disable GetForceTorqueWithAppliedForce for bullet and create an issue or will it be easy to fix?
content.html: Should I just disable GetForceTorqueWithAppliedForce for bullet and create an issue or will it be easy to fix?

issue.title: Enable Joint ForceTorque Tests for Bullet

content.raw: I think #619 should fix this problem.
content.html: I think #619 should fix this problem.

issue.title: Enable Joint ForceTorque Tests for Bullet

content.raw:
Time step size of about 0.0002s stabilizes the system with active controllers and joint damping, but runs very slowly.  Curiously though, smaller time step size of 0.0001s does not yield correct results.

@scpeters  Let's disable this test and refer to issue #619 for now.
content.html:
Time step size of about 0.0002s stabilizes the system with active controllers and joint damping, but runs very slowly. Curiously though, smaller time step size of 0.0001s does not yield correct results.

@scpeters Let's disable this test and refer to issue #619 for now.
